What property of the bpdo ligand makes it a suitable partner for hard Group II Mg(II) and Ca(II) ions in the synthesis of PCPs?
data.answer: The bpdo ligand has hard basicity, derived from its polarized structure, which causes the neutral bpdo to bridge hard Mg(II) and Ca(II) ions.

data.question: What is the main advantage of using Group II metal ions, Mg(II) and Ca(II), in the construction of PCPs over first-transition-row divalent metal ions?
data.answer: Group II metal ions, Mg(II) and Ca(II), could provide cheaper materials and lead to enhanced biocompatibility.

data.question: How does the CO2 adsorption capacity of the synthesized Mg(II) and Ca(II) PCPs compare at ambient temperature?
data.answer: The synthesized Mg(II) and Ca(II) PCPs show selective adsorption and separation of carbon dioxide over methane at ambient temperature.

data.question: What is the role of the charge-polarized neutral 'bpdo' ligand in the diversification of Mg(II) and Ca(II) PCP frameworks?
data.answer: The charge-polarized neutral 'bpdo' ligand, due to its hard basicity, acts as a bridging ligand for hard Group II Mg(II) and Ca(II) ions, contributing to the structural diversification of their PCP frameworks.

data.question: What experimental technique was used to determine the crystal structures of the synthesized PCPs?
data.answer: Single-crystal X-ray crystallography was used to determine the crystal structures of the synthesized PCPs.

data.question: True or False: The synthesized Mg(II) and Ca(II) PCPs are unstable after the removal of guest molecules.
What is the significance of the calculated NBO charges on the oxygen atoms of the bpdo ligand in the context of coordinating to Group II metal ions?
data.answer: The calculated NBO charges on the oxygen atoms of the bpdo ligand indicate that the ligand has hard basicity and is a good partner for hard Group II Mg(II) and Ca(II) ions, as it can coordinate to these ions through negatively charged oxygen atoms.

data.question: True or False: The synthesized PCPs using bpdo ligands do not show any selectivity in gas adsorption.
What is the potential application of the synthesized Mg(II) and Ca(II) PCPs in environmental technology?
data.answer: The synthesized Mg(II) and Ca(II) PCPs have potential applications in carbon dioxide capture and separation due to their selective adsorption properties.
